p.span: OGISD Community:

With sadness, we report that school closure has been extended by Governor Abbott for the remainder of the school year. The many remaining activities that bring life and closure to our school year have now been cancelled. None of us will forget this experience, especially our students who wanted and expected so much more from their time inside our school buildings and on the competitive field. Unfortunately, we end the experience of moving from class to class and completing extra-curricular activities for the 2019-2020 school year. We are not alone in this regard.

And so we move forward. At-home learning continues, with work to complete and effort to demonstrate before the end of the grading period. Although the school experience has changed dramatically, teachers and staff still expect instruction and the learning that comes with it to continue. We still have much to accomplish. Please work closely with your teachers to get the job done!

Graduation for our seniors is still very much on our minds. We have developed scenarios to send our students out with a “ceremony,” but we must still wait, for the virus to pass and for clearance to hold such a ceremony. Even with our plans, so much is still unknown about when, where, and how we will conduct graduation. We will announce news on this front as soon as we learn more.

The University Interscholastic League (UIL) governs extra-curricular activities. We will wait for more information from them before we announce, if we announce, summer activities. Our athletic director, Coach DelPercio, will provide information as it develops. We plan to be ready for next year in a big way!
We also know that many students still have possessions and textbooks in lockers. Each campus, at the appropriate time, will announce our process for students to secure these items at a later date.

We need everyone to join with us on our parent messaging system – Blackboard Connect. This tool is used by the District and campuses to communicate timely information. On the OGISD District website, instructions to join can be found under the News and Announcements section. If you have not done so, please do. Don’t forget to sign up for our gradebook portal so that you can monitor your child’s grades on a regular basis. Please contact the campus administrative assistant for your child’s portal ID. Monitoring is a great way to know more about your child’s school day!

Once again, the work to excel continues, only in a much different format. Electronic instruction and paper packets are being utilized each week. Contact your principal if you are facing challenges in assisting your child’s effort to complete required work.

The OGISD School Board will consider for approval changes to our grading system in light of school closure. This document, after approval, will be posted on our District website and communicated to students and parents next week. Please look for this information as it is made available.

em.span: Our doors may be closed, but the learning continues! Join with us to make it happen!

em.span: ov.
Greg Abbott

on Friday announced initial steps to begin the process of reopening the Texas economy during the coronavirus pandemic, including those that in the next week will loosen surgery restrictions at medical facilities, allow all retail stores to provide product pickups and reopen state parks.

Abbott also named a "statewide strike force" devoted to developing reopening procedures. Austin banker James Huffines will chair the task force, while veteran lobbyist Mike Toomey will be its chief operating officer. The group will oversee what Abbott described as a phased reopening.

That first phase came in a series of executive orders issued Friday. One order allows for product pickup at retail stores — what Abbott described as "retail-to-go" — that will begin April 24. Outlets will be allowed to bring orders straight to customers' cars in a manner similar to how many restaurants are currently offering curbside pickup.

Another order, which goes into effect Tuesday night, will allow a limited amount of nonessential surgeries at hospitals, as long as those surgeries don't deplete the hospitals' supplies of personal protective equipment and allow the facilities to keep at least 25% of their capacity available for the treatment of patients with COVID-19, the illness caused by the new coronavirus.
A third order will allow state parks to open Monday. Visitors to parks will be required to wear masks and keep a safe distance from people outside their households.
Additional openings will be announced April 27 "after further input from medical staff," Abbott said.

"Even more openings will be announced in May when it is determined that the infection rate continues to decline and when testing capabilities are sufficient to test and contain" outbreaks of the virus," he said.

Abbott didn't detail what those later opening would entail. He did announce, however, that schools — public schools, private schools and universities — will remain closed for the rest of the school year.
Source: Texas Tribune, April, 17, 2020

p.span: OGISD Community:

You hear it all the time during flu season: wash your hands to prevent the spread of flu. You may have heard advice encouraging you to do the same to stop the spread of COVID-19. But do you know why this simple practice works so effectively? Washing your hands with soap and water breaks up the molecules of the virus and washes them away, preventing the virus from infecting you or others.

To be able to effectively and reliably break up the virus cells, you must wash your hands thoroughly and vigorously for at least 20 seconds. Doing this can be incredibly effective! In fact, a study showed that when a group of elementary aged school children participated in supervised handwashing 2-4 times per day, the spread of a similar virus was reduced by 47%
While it is important to wash your hands, it is also important that we all regularly disinfect surfaces.

COVID-19 has been shown to live for up to three days on various surfaces. If you must leave your home for essential services, be sure to wash your hands as soon as you return and disinfect any surfaces you may have touched. If someone in your home is ill, it’s also important to regularly disinfect. Applying soap and water plus commonly used disinfectants to frequently touched surfaces will break up the virus and carry it away, in the same way soap kills and carries away the virus on your hands.

We hope you and your family are able to regularly take these simple steps, which will help prevent the spread of COVID-19, and help your family to stay well. For more information on preventing the spread of COVID-19, visit

p.span: OGISD Community:

Orange Grove ISD will be closed until further notice as our community continues to work together to contain the spread of COVID-19. All OGISD facilities and grounds will continue to be closed for instruction and other purposes. OGISD continues to work closely with our Mayor, officials from Jim Wells County, and our state officials to monitor the health and safety of our community.

OGISD continues to provide online instructional and support services as planned. This includes making available instructional packets that may be received from the campus for those students lacking internet access. We also want to make clear that our effort to provide instructional materials is a work in progress. We are monitoring our process and making improvements where needed. Please bear with us in this regard. Student learning, in this new form, must continue during this period of school closure.

We are so appreciative of the work that parents and students are doing to facilitate instruction and learning directly in the home. Contact your child’s teacher by email and/or the campus principal for additional questions.
In response to the Jim Wells County Stay at Home Order, office hours for campuses to receive emails and phone calls have been reduced to the following during this period of closure:
Monday through Thursday, 8am-11am.

Meal service (breakfast and lunch packages issued curbside) is available to all children, 18 or younger, for the duration of this closure. Please know that this effort is very important to all of us. Pick-up locations include the OGISD Elementary cafeteria and the Sandia Community Center from 10am-12pm.
Use the OGISD website (COVID-19) for additional information and important links.

em.span: Austin-Travis County interim Health Authority Dr. Mark Escott on Thursday said new data from University of Texas modeling the projected spread of the coronavirus showed that reducing personal interactions by 90% in coming weeks would save thousands of lives in the greater Austin community alone. “The data shows us that if we were to go back to school in a week, if we were to turn the restaurants and bars back on in a week, if we were returned to business as normal in a week, as some have recommended that we do, by the middle of May, we will be in a catastrophe situation like other jurisdictions are facing right now across the United States and across the world,” Escott said. “That is not an option. What we have to do is delay this as long as we can.”

OGISD Community:
This message shares a summary of information from Governor Abbott’s executive order on COVID-19, courtesy of the Texas School Policy Network:

em.span:
Governor Abbott issued an executive order which adopts federal and CDC standards across the entire state of Texas to contain COVID-19. The order becomes effective at midnight March 20 and continues through midnight on April 3rd (subject to extension).
The executive order includes the following mandate:

All schools in the state of Texas shall be temporarily closed. Governor Abbott stated that this does not mean education stops – superintendents should continue to work with the Texas Education Agency to continue online or additional educational options.
The order also stated the following:
Every person in Texas shall avoid social gatherings in groups of more than 10.

No dine-in service at restaurants, bars, or food courts, and gyms shall be closed. The use of drive-through, pick-up, and delivery service is allowed, and highly encouraged throughout the limited duration of the executive order.
People shall not visit nursing homes, retirement homes, or long-term care facilities unless to provide critical assistance.

The Governor made sure to emphasize that this executive order is not a "shelter in place" order. It does not prohibit people from doing things like going to the grocery store, gas stations, parks, or banks. All critical infrastructure will remain open and operational. Domestic travel remains unrestricted. Essential services by government entities will continued to be provided. Only essential employees should be to be asked to come in, and work from home encouraged. The goal of these requirements is to slow the spread of COVID-19.

p.span: As of

the morning of March 20, the Texas Department State Health Services has not posted any confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Jim Wells, Kleberg, Nueces, Duval or Live Oak counties. We still must remain vigilant and work hard and smart to prevent further exposure in our community and state. As such, the Texas DSHS shares these important reminders during this crisis period:

h3.style: margin-top: 0in; line-height: 15.0pt; background: white; vertical-align: baseline

em.span: How can Texans slow the spread of COVID-19?
The next two weeks are critical in slowing the spread of COVID-19. Texans must act now.
Stay home as much as possible, especially if you are sick, older, and/or have a medical condition.
If you are sick, stay home except to access medical care. If you are able to take care of yourself, stay home. If you need to see your doctor, call ahead.
Avoid gatherings of more than 10 people and non-essential trips into public.
Cancel events of more than 10 people.
Limit close contact (at least six feet) with other people. Employers should allow alternative work options as much as possible.

p.style: background: white; vertical-align: baseline; margin: 0px 12pt 0.0001pt 27pt; padding: 0px

h3.style: margin-top: 0in; line-height: 15.0pt; background: white; vertical-align: baseline

em.span: What else can people do to protect themselves and others?
Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands.
Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue, then throw the tissue in the trash.
Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.

p.span: We can do this together! America is strong today and always.
Sincerely,
Randy Hoyer, Superintendent of Schools

Given the rapidly evolving situation with COVID-19, OGISD will extend the suspension of normal District operations through Friday, April 3, in an effort to support our nation’s need to slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, or COVID-19. Health officials report that cases are continuing to spread in the state, and confirmed cases in our county seems not only possible, but likely with increased testing. Suspending operations for this length of time will allow us to determine, in coordination with local health officials, whether the virus will have community spread or whether it has been contained. We are coordinating with other school districts in the county and will use the last week of March to make any decisions on whether there is a need to extend the suspension further.

Providing a sense of possible impact will help all of us prepare: If there is a need to continue the suspension of school district operations, it would likely be for at least three (3) more weeks beyond April 3. This is a highly fluid situation and changes may well occur.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has outlined the need for all communities to implement a social distancing protocol. We want to reiterate a request to our broader community to take the following reasonable precautions to prevent the spread of the illness:

li.span: Limit movement within the community, especially avoiding crowded places and maintaining 3 to 6 ft of distance between people (at least an arm’s length)
If you are moving around in the community, don’t congregate in large groups

For those who have traveled to areas with known COVID-19 cases – both inside and outside of the country – self-quarantine and monitor for symptoms. Students who have traveled should plan to stay home for two weeks after arriving home. This will be considered an excused absence.
If you suspect you have symptoms of COVID-19, call your health care provider for medical advice .
Keep your child at home if he/she feels ill, even if you think it is just a cold.
Do not leave the house if you are ill, except to access medical care

span.br: This is a quickly changing situation, and we will continue to monitor information, assess conditions in the weeks ahead, and provide the updates as conditions warrant through our social media sites.

p.span: We have posted a link, COVID-19, on our District website that will provide information from the superintendent, the Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS), the Center for Disease Control (CDC), and Texas Education Agency (TEA). All of these sites provide information from which our school district makes the decision to open or close, based on the most up-to-date guidance.

The District is providing a meal (grab and go) for all students between 10:00 am - 12:00 pm. This meal is at no cost to families and is for OGISD students only. Over 100 meals have been served on the first day.

td.style: width: 395.1pt; border: solid windowtext 1.0pt; padding: 0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt; height: 131.35pt

em.span: For Immediate Release
March 17
OGISD and Aramark, our food service provider, will offer to-go meals from 10:00 am-12:00 pm beginning March 18 through our period of closure. This is for weekdays only, Monday through Friday.
The pickup location is outside the elementary campus cafeteria. Each meal packet will include a breakfast and lunch in the same packet. Meals will be available while supplies last.
As per federal guidelines, meals will be issued to OGISD children 18 and younger. One meal per child. Adults will not be allowed to pick up meals for children who are not present.
Please remain in the vehicle and staff will assist in delivery.

p.span: Due to COVID-19, all District offices will have restricted hours: Monday-Thursday, 8:00-12:00 pm. We are also going to restrict access to our buildings in an abundance of caution. This scenario continues during our period of closure. Offices will remain available to receive emails and phone calls during hours of operation.

We have worked to provide some form of instruction to the children in our schools during the time our District is closed. Please consider the challenge in accomplishing this task: moving instruction from the classroom to outside the classroom. Principals at each campus are working hard with their teachers to create and distribute educational materials. Your point of contact for this effort is the campus principal and your child’s teacher. Expect communication by email, postings on the campus websites, and/or text messages for additional information.
Sincerely,
Randy Hoyer, Superintendent of Schools
